review.title: A Combinatorial Algebraic Approach for the Identifiability of Low-Rank Matrix Completion
review.abstract: In this paper, we review the problem of matrix completion and expose its intimate relations with algebraic geometry, combinatorics and graph theory. We present the first necessary and sufficient combinatorial conditions for matrices of arbitrary rank to be identifiable from a set of matrix entries, yielding theoretical constraints and new algorithms for the problem of matrix completion. We conclude by algorithmically evaluating the tightness of the given conditions and algorithms for practically relevant matrix sizes, showing that the algebraic-combinatoric approach can lead to improvements over state-of-the-art matrix completion methods.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this thesis we have introduced a basic combinatorial algebra framework for the matrix completion problem, with which we were able to derive the first known necessary and sufficient conditions for the completion of a matrix in relation to the set of known entries, building on the introduced techniques that combine matrix completion with combinatorial graph theory and algebraic geometry. As a by-product, we have also obtained graph theoretical results. Subject to this sufficient condition, we have also been able to formulate an algorithm for the matrix completion problem that has proven to be competitive with known matrix completion algorithms and that works better than modern methods for small ranks. The results obtained lead us to argue that the study of the interactions between machine learning, algebraic geometry and combinatories has the potential to be extremely advantageous for the problem of matrix completion from any point of view.
